docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration may have pushed the bounds of its legal authority by delaying the healthcare law requirement that certain employers provide coverage to full-time workers, but the move will be tough to challenge in court, according to legal experts.

headline.main: Healthcare Mandate Delay May Be Illegal, but Challenges Unlikely - Experts

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama on Tuesday defended the latest delay in his healthcare law's employer mandate, saying it follows similar relief his administration has already given to certain individuals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Monday again delayed a contentious healthcare law requirement that all but the smallest employers provide coverage to full-time workers, this time by giving medium-sized businesses another year to comply.

Dave Camp, R-Mich., after the Obama administration granted employers another delay in a heavily criticized requirement that medium-to-larger firms provide their workers with health insurance or face fines.

docs.lead_paragraph: AOL’s chief, Tim Armstrong, set off a firestorm among American workers by publicly revealing information about medical costs for two babies covered by company health plans.

headline.main: Revelations by AOL Boss Raise Fears Over Privacy
headline.print_headline: Revelations by AOL Boss Raise Fears Over Privacy

docs.abstract: AOL’s chief executive Tim Armstrong sets off firestorm among American workers by publicly revealing information about medical costs for two babies covered by company health plans; patient and work force experts say gaffe could have lasting impact on how comfortable--or discomfited--Americans feel about bosses' data-mining their personal lives.
docs.snippet: AOL’s chief, Tim Armstrong, set off a firestorm among American workers by publicly revealing information about medical costs for two babies covered by company health plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Raghuveer Nayak, 58, of Chicago, had pleaded to charges that he bribed doctors to refer patients to surgery centers he owned.

headline.main: Illinois: Fund-Raiser Sentenced for Health Care Fraud
headline.print_headline: Illinois: Fund-Raiser Sentenced for Health Care Fraud

docs.abstract: Federal judge in Chicago sentences Raghuveer Nayak, former fund-raiser for former Gov Rod Blagojevich and former Rep Jesse Jackson Jr, to two years in prison on charges of health care fraud.
docs.snippet: Raghuveer Nayak, 58, of Chicago, had pleaded to charges that he bribed doctors to refer patients to surgery centers he owned.

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing pressure from conservative challengers, several lawmakers who supported a plan to expand health insurance for the poor could change course.

headline.main: In Arkansas, ‘Private Option’ Medicaid Plan Could Be Derailed
headline.print_headline: In Arkansas, ‘Private Option’ Medicaid Plan Could Be Derailed

docs.abstract: Several Republican lawmakers in Arkansas, facing pressure from conservative primary challengers, are reconsidering their support for plan to use federal Medicaid expansion funds to buy private insurance for poor people; abrupt reversal, even as idea is gaining support in other states, could leave 83,000 people who have signed up so far without insurance.
docs.snippet: Facing pressure from conservative challengers, several lawmakers who supported a plan to expand health insurance for the poor could change course.
